oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hiawatha Lake in Onondaga Park Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lake Hiawatha was originally a city reservoir with rip-rapped stone sides and adjoined to an Oak and Hickory grove. This was a popular place for picnicking, swimming and fishing. The reservoir was soon transformed into a lake and lagoon and the whole area landscaped with planting and roads. An annual fishing derby every summer is a popular event for families from nearby towns. Beaches along the lake offer residents an area to relax and sun- bathe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: The Syracuse News Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards
Geography & Maps;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Color illustration postcard with written message on reverse.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The Library is providing access to these materials for educational and research purposed. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Picturesque View of Hiawatha Lake Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lake Hiawatha was originally a city reservoir with rip-rapped stone sides and adjoined to an Oak and Hickory grove. This was a popular place for picnicking, swimming and fishing. The reservoir was soon transformed into a lake and lagoon and the whole area landscaped with planting and roads. An annual fishing derby every summer is a popular event for families from nearby towns. Beaches along the lake offer residents an area to relax and sun- bathe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wm. Jubb Co., Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards
Geography & Maps;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Post Card Hiawatha Lake was named in memory of a great Chief of the Iroquois Indians whose legendary home was near the present site of the City of Syracuse. The lake is used as a public swimming pool in summer and as a skating rink in winter. Miss Emalyn Crael Kelly Station Pa. Hello Emalyn, Well, sure wish the weather as nice down as its up here today. So long, Esther

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pond, Onondaga Park, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Purchased by the city of Syracuse July 27, 1898, Onondaga Park offers the city a variety of recreational activities. Onondaga Park is the only City Park which includes a large bady of water, Lake Hiawatha, which is mostly used for fishing and attributes to the park's overall beauty. The Lily Pond was constructed near the Onondaga Avenue entrance to the Park in the 1930s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rudolph Bros., Manufacturers

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Park- The Stone Arch Bridge, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Purchased by the City of Syracuse July 27, 1898, Onondaga Park offers the city a variety of recreational activities. Onondaga Park is the only City Park which includes a large body of water, Lake Hiawatha, which is mostly used for fishing and attributes to the park's overall beauty. In 1913, along with many other additions, a stone footbridge was added.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Swimming Pool, Old Reservoir, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Purchased by the city of Syracuse July 27, 1898, Onondaga Park offers the city a variety of recreational activities. Onondaga Park is the only city park which includes a large body of water, Lake Hiawatha. Originally Lake Hiawatha was a city reservoir with rip-rapped stone sides and adjoined to an Oak and Hickory grove. This was a popular place for picnicking, swimming, and fishing. Beaches along the lake offer residents an area to relax and sun- bathe.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Park, Syracuse N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Onondaga Park was purchased by the City of Syracuse on July 27, 1898. It is the only City Park which includes a large body of water, Lake Hiawatha, which is mostly used for fishing and attributes to the park's overall beauty. Upper Onondaga Park was designated as the city's first Historic Landscape in 1987.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Park- the Island and Band Stand, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1911, an island was constructed in the middle of Hiawatha Lake that was 65 feet in diameter. In 1914, a bandstand was constructed on the center of the island. Each summer, music from local band's instruments delighted crowds often numbering in the thousands.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bathing Pavilion, Onondaga Park, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Onondaga Park bathhouse was constructed from 1914 to 1915. This addition began the park's brightest era. On hot summer days, Syracusans enjoyed not only the refreshment of the lake, but also relaxed in the park's many picnic groves and played at its ballfields.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Park Fishing Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hiawatha Lake fishing lures the small fry. For the grownups swimming and tennis nearby. Lake Hiawatha was originally a city reservoir with rip-rapped stone sides and adjoined to an Oak and Hickory grove. This was a popular place for picnicking, swimming and fishing. The reservoir was soon transformed into a lake and lagoon and the whole area landscaped with planting and roads. An annual fishing derby every summer is a popular event for families from nearby towns. Beaches along the lake offer residents an area to relax and sun- bathe.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lake and Walk, Onondaga Park, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lake Hiawatha was originally a city reservoir with rip-rapped stone sides and adjoined to an Oak and Hickory grove. This was a popular place for picnicking, swimming and fishing. The reservoir was soon transformed into a lake and lagoon and the whole area landscaped with planting and roads. An annual fishing derby every summer is a popular event for families from nearby towns. Beaches along the lake offer residents an area to relax and sun- bathe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wm. Jubb Co., Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bathing Pavilion, Hiawatha Lake, Onondaga Park, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Onondaga Park bathhouse was constructed from 1914 to 1915. This addition began the park's brightest era. On hot summer days, Syracusans enjoyed not only the refreshment of the lake, but also relaxed in the park's many picnic groves and played at its ballfields.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wm. Jubb Co., Inc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scene at Onondaga Park, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Purchased by the City of Syracuse July 27, 1898, Onondaga Park offers the city a variety of recreational activities. Onondaga Park is the only city park which includes a large body of water, Lake Hiawatha, which is mostly used for fishing and attributes to the park's overall beauty. The Upper Onondaga Park was designated the city's first Historic Landscape in 1987.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rudolph Bros., Manufacturers

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Band Stand, Onondaga Park, Syracuse, N.Y. Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Purchased by the city of Syracuse July 27, 1898, Onondaga Park offers the city a variety of recreational activities. The bandstand was built in 1914 on a small island just off the shore of Lake Hiawatha. Crowds in the thousands would congregate to listen to music from local bands.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wm. Jubb Co., Inc.
